Q: clean way to run modern C++ code at function exit if it may throw A:

I find this comes up all the time: I want something to happen before a function exits successfully, regardless of return path. This "something" might involve throwing an exception, but if the stack is unwinding due to some other exception, it's fine for the "something" not to happen.

I understand the ambiguity when multiple exceptions are active and why destructors shouldn't throw. I posed this question because the sanctioned advice out there seems to be "don't do this", and I think what I'm doing is absolutely commonplace in the course of professional production C++ development!

I need a way for the compiler to help me ensure I don't forget a return path. The "flag" is just a toy example - it could be anything that needs to happen on (successful!) function exit. I feel there should be a way to indicate the logic in my "wrapped" function above without actually having to wrap the function every time.

In real life I need the "flagging" to throw because it's actually 20 function calls deep and very complex, and it needs to return control to an outer loop on exception. I need the compiler to help because the "complicated flow control" is too complicated for me to catch every return path. I understand that there is some theoretically cleaner approach, but I'm curious whether others can relate to how often this situation comes up for them.. and how painful it is that the scope_guard can't really handle this when exceptions are involved.

Q: NULL column value from LEFT JOINed table overwrites column with identical name in parent table when using CodeIgniter's select('*') A: 
$this->db
    ->select('*')
    ->select('users.user_id')
    ->from('users')
    ->join('user_profile', 'user_profile.user_id = users.user_id', 'LEFT')
    ->join('user_profile_images', 'user_profile_images.image_id = user_profile.profile_image_id', 'LEFT')
    ->group_by('users.user_id')
    ->where('users.user_id', $user_id);
$query = $this->db->get();

Q: Setting a variable in batch using powershell A:

setlocal EnableExtensions & for /F "usebackq delims=" %%G IN (`powershell "((Get-date).AddDays(-1)).ToString('yyyyMMdd')"`) do set yesterday=%%G

If batch file extensions are enabled by default on the system, "setlocal EnableExtensions & " may be omitted.

Q: Avalonia UI on Arch Linux (Hyprland) - Android/iOS builds fail with [NETSDK1139] error - Workaround? A:

I ran into the same thing just last night, it was almost 5am here before I finished fiddling with this, so I may have missed something.

I originally had Rider and Android Studio installed via Snap.

I had to redo the my installation of Rider and Android Studio because I had done so many things trying to get this working that I just wanted a clean slate, so I removed the Rider and Android Studio snaps instead and did these steps:

  1. Install the Jetbrains Toolbox from here.

  2. Install Rider AND Android Studio using the Jetbrains Toolbox.

  3. You probably have them installed by now, but of course you'll need the .NET Sdks and Avalonia.Template

  4. Install openjdk with your package manager. You'll need the JDK, not just the JRE.

  5. Run Rider and go to settings. On the left pane, go to Build, Execute, Deployment -> Android.

    1. In the main part of the dialog, Android SDK Location, put in the absolute path where your android SDK is. On mine it lives in $HOME/Android/Sdk. If you don't have one, there's a link right under the text box to Install New which will install the SDK.

  6. Optional: File -> Invalidate Caches... (you can do this any time, when you have a project open)

Unless you're on really beefy hardware, use a physical device for debugging. The emulator is dog slow.

I'm not sure if installing Android Studio is really necessary, but it can't hurt. I'll try redoing it without Android studio sometime later (where later might be today, tomorrow or any point in the future)
